Article 5
(1) A minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act;provided, however, that this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.
(2) A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable.
(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.

The hypothesis is False.

The given premise discusses the legal capacity of minors to enter into juridical acts, such as contracts, and the necessity of obtaining the consent of their legal representative. However, the premise does not mention anything about accepting an offer of gifts without a burden.

Therefore, it cannot be concluded from the given premise whether the acceptance made by a minor that received an offer of gifts without burden without getting consent from his/her statutory agent may or may not be rescinded. It would depend on the specific circumstances and the laws governing such situations in the relevant jurisdiction.

Article 6
(1) A minor who is permitted to conduct one or multiple types of business has the same capacity to act as an adult as far as that business is concerned.
(2) In a case as referred to in the preceding paragraph, if there are grounds that make the minor unable to sustain that business, the legal representative may revoke or limit the permission therefor in accordance with the provisions of Part IV (Relatives).
t2: If a minor, after getting permission for carrying a business from his/her statutory agent, performs an act unrelated to the business without getting consent of the statutory agent, that act may not be rescinded.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is True.

According to the given premise, a minor who is permitted to conduct one or multiple types of business has the same capacity to act as an adult as far as that business is concerned, and the legal representative may revoke or limit the permission if there are grounds that make the minor unable to sustain that business. However, the premise does not mention anything about acts unrelated to the business.

Therefore, it can be concluded that if a minor, after getting permission for carrying a business from his/her statutory agent, performs an act unrelated to the business without getting the consent of the statutory agent, that act may not be rescinded. The legal capacity of the minor to act as an adult in the specific business allowed by the legal representative does not extend to unrelated acts.

t2: The purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is True.

The given premise states that a juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable, but there are exceptions to this rule. Specifically, the purchase of daily necessities or any other act involved in day-to-day life is not voidable. 

Therefore, it can be concluded that the purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act. This exception exists to ensure that adult wards are able to make necessary purchases for their day-to-day life without undue interference or intervention.

t2: If a person under curatorship performs, without getting the consent, an act that requires  getting consent from his/her curator, the curator may ratify that act, but may not rescind that act.

According to the given premise, if a person under curatorship performs an act that requires the consent of the curator without obtaining such consent, that act is voidable. However, if the person under curatorship performs such an act, and it is unlikely to prejudice their interests, the family court may grant permission that operates in lieu of the curator's consent at the request of the person under curatorship.

Furthermore, Article 122 provides that a voidable act may not be rescinded after the person prescribed in Article 120 ratifies it. Therefore, if the curator ratifies the act performed by the person under curatorship without obtaining the required consent, the act cannot be rescinded.

However, the premise does not explicitly state that the curator may ratify the act in question. The only reference to the curator's role is in relation to their consent or lack thereof and the possibility of seeking permission from the family court if the curator does not consent. Therefore, while it is true that the act may not be rescinded if the curator ratifies it, it cannot be concluded from the given premise whether the curator has the power to do so.

Article 189
(1) A possessor in good faith acquires fruits derived from the thing under possession.
(2) If a possessor in good faith is defeated in an action on the title that legally supports the possession, that possessor is deemed to be a possessor in bad faith as from the time when the action is filed.
Article 190
(1) A possessor in bad faith has the obligation to return fruits, and reimburse the price of fruits that the possessor has already consumed, damaged due to negligence, or failed to collect.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph apply mutatis mutandis to a person who takes possession of a thing through assault or duress or through concealment.
t2: A possessor in good faith shall acquire fruits derived from  Thing in his/her possession , but a person in possession Thing through duress shall be obliged to return fruits, and if the fruits have already been consumed, he/she shall be obliged  to reimburse the cost of the fruits.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is True.

According to the given premise, a possessor in good faith acquires fruits derived from the thing under possession, while a possessor in bad faith has the obligation to return fruits and reimburse the price of fruits that they have already consumed, damaged due to negligence, or failed to collect. 

Additionally, the provisions of Article 190 apply mutatis mutandis to a person who takes possession of a thing through duress, which means that they are also obliged to return fruits and reimburse the cost of fruits that have already been consumed.

Therefore, it can be concluded that a possessor in good faith shall acquire fruits derived from the thing in their possession, but a person in possession of a thing through duress shall be obliged to return fruits, and if the fruits have already been consumed, they shall be obliged to reimburse the cost of the fruits.

ChatGPT_output:

Article 89
(1) The ownership of natural fruits is acquired by the person entitled to obtain them when they are separated from the original thing.
(2) A person acquires civil fruits in proportion to the duration of the right to obtain them, as calculated on a prorated, daily basis.
t2: If person A donates a house that he/she is renting to person C with a provision for the payment of rent at the end of every month to person B midway through the month, if there is a special agreement between person A and person B, the rent for the month will be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of the days.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is True.

According to the given premise, a person acquires civil fruits in proportion to the duration of the right to obtain them, as calculated on a prorated, daily basis. 

In the scenario described in the hypothesis, person A donates a house that they are renting to person C, with a provision for the payment of rent at the end of every month to person B, midway through the month. If there is a special agreement between person A and person B, the rent for the month will be distributed between person A and person B in proportion to the number of days.

This is because person B has the right to receive rent for a portion of the month, and the prorated calculation ensures that person A receives compensation for the period of time that the property was under their ownership and control, while person B receives compensation for the period of time that they have the right to collect rent.

Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the person performing an obligation from exercising the right to reimbursement against the obligor.

The hypothesis is True.

According to the given premise, if a person who is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake, and the obligee, acting in good faith, has waived the security, the person performing the obligation may not demand the return of the subject matter of the performance. This means that the person who performed the obligation cannot demand the return of what was given or done, even if the obligee waived the security in good faith.

It is important to note that this provision applies regardless of whether the person performing the obligation was grossly negligent or not. However, the person performing the obligation may still exercise the right to reimbursement against the obligor, according to the second paragraph of Article 707.

Therefore, it can be concluded that in cases where a person who is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake, if the obligee waived the security in good faith, the person that performed the obligation may not demand return of the performance, even without having been grossly negligent.

t1:
Article 206
An owner has the rights to freely use, profit from and dispose of the thing owned, within the limits of laws and regulations.
t2: If person B hinders the exercise of ownership for a thing owned by person A using methods other than possession of the thing, person A's ability to demand the removal or discontinuance of the disturbance from B based on ownership is limited to when person A incurs serious and considerable irreparable damage due to person B's disturbance.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is True.

According to the given premise, an owner has the rights to freely use, profit from and dispose of the thing owned, within the limits of laws and regulations. However, if person B hinders the exercise of ownership for a thing owned by person A using methods other than possession of the thing, person A's ability to demand the removal or discontinuance of the disturbance from B based on ownership is limited to when person A incurs serious and considerable irreparable damage due to person B's disturbance.

This means that if person B is using methods other than possession of the thing to hinder person A's exercise of ownership, person A's right to demand the removal or discontinuance of the disturbance is limited to cases where the disturbance causes serious and considerable irreparable damage to person A. In other words, person A cannot demand the removal or discontinuance of the disturbance simply because their ownership is being hindered, but only when the disturbance causes significant harm that cannot be easily repaired or compensated.

Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 181
Possessory rights may be acquired through an agent.
t2: An agent may even acquire a possessory right, but since the effect of possession by the agent belongs to the principle, the agent him/herself may not acquire an individual possessory right for the thing possessed.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is true.

According to the given premise, possessory rights may be acquired through an agent, which means that an agent may possess a thing on behalf of the principal and acquire possessory rights in the same way as the principal. However, the effect of the possession by the agent belongs to the principal, and the agent themselves may not acquire an individual possessory right for the thing possessed.

This means that while an agent may possess a thing and acquire possessory rights through that possession, those rights belong to the principal and not the agent. The agent does not have a separate or individual possessory right for the thing possessed. The possession by the agent is considered to be on behalf of the principal, and any possessory rights acquired through that possession are also considered to be on behalf of the principal.

Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

Article 201
(1) An action for maintenance of possession must be filed during the obstruction or within one year after the obstruction stops;provided, however, that if the possessed thing has been damaged due to construction work and either one year has passed from the time when the construction was started or the construction has been completed, the action may not be filed.
(2) An action for preservation of possession may be filed so long as the danger of obstruction exists.In this case, the provisions of the proviso to the preceding paragraph apply mutatis mutandis if the possessed thing is likely to be damaged by the construction work.
(3) An action for recovery of possession must be filed within one year from the time when a possessor was forcibly dispossessed.
t2: An action for recovery of possession mustl be brought within one year from the time when possession was unlawfully usurped.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is false.

According to the given premise, an action for recovery of possession must be filed within one year from the time when a possessor was forcibly dispossessed. This means that if a possessor was forcibly removed from their possession, they have one year from that time to file an action for recovery of possession.

However, the hypothesis states that an action for recovery of possession must be brought within one year from the time when possession was unlawfully usurped. This is not entirely correct. While it is true that a possessor may bring an action for recovery of possession if their possession has been unlawfully usurped, the time limit for bringing such an action is different.

If a possessor's possession has been unlawfully usurped, they may file an action for recovery of possession at any time while the usurper remains in possession. There is no time limit for bringing an action in this case, as long as the usurper remains in possession.

Therefore, the hypothesis is false. The time limit for bringing an action for recovery of possession is not based on the time when possession was unlawfully usurped, but rather on the time when a possessor was forcibly dispossessed.
